summary: Critical risk: 7 critical company standard violations requiring immediate attention

flags.title: Missing Termination Clause
flags.description: Contract clause for termination is missing.
flags.recommendation: The termination clause is a fundamental part of any contract. Its absence creates significant legal and business risk, as it leaves the parties without a clear framework for ending the agreement. This needs to be added immediately.

flags.title: Significant deviation in payment terms and pricing model
flags.description: The contract clause does not specify a payment due date (e.g., net 30 days).; The contract clause does not mention any late payment fees or interest.; The contract clause does not specify how invoices will be issued or delivered.; The contract clause uses a cost-plus or fair market value approach for charging services, which is fundamentally different from the standard net 30 payment terms.
flags.recommendation: The contract clause significantly deviates from company standards. It lacks essential payment terms such as due dates and late fees, and proposes a different pricing model (cost-plus/fair market value) instead of standard payment terms. This clause should be renegotiated to align with the company standard payment terms, including specifying invoice issuance, payment due dates, and late fee provisions.

flags.title: Missing Indemnification Clause
flags.description: Indemnification clause is completely missing from the contract.
flags.recommendation: The indemnification clause is a critical component of risk allocation in a contract. Its absence creates significant legal and business risk for the company. This clause must be added to the contract and should align with the company standard clause provided.

flags.title: Missing Confidentiality Clause
flags.description: The contract clause for confidentiality is missing entirely (null value provided).
flags.recommendation: The confidentiality clause must be inserted into the contract to protect sensitive information. A clause similar to the company standard should be used, ensuring clear definitions of confidential information, obligations of the receiving party, and exclusions from confidentiality.

flags.title: Missing Intellectual Property Clause
flags.description: The contract clause is missing entirely, which represents a critical gap in intellectual property protection.
flags.recommendation: The contract clause for intellectual property is entirely absent. This is a critical omission. The company standard clause, which assigns all intellectual property developed during the performance of services to the company, must be included in the contract.

flags.title: Absence of Warranty Clause
flags.description: The contract clause for warranties is null, meaning no warranties are included in the contract. This is a significant deviation from the company standard, which includes express warranties for workmanship, materials, and substantial performance in accordance with documentation.
flags.recommendation: The contract must include a warranty clause that aligns with the company standard. Specifically, it should warrant that the Product/Service provided will be free from defects in workmanship and materials for a period of ninety (90) days from the Effective Date and will perform substantially in accordance with the Documentation during such warranty period.

flags.title: Missing Dispute Resolution Clause
flags.description: Contract clause for dispute resolution is missing entirely.
flags.recommendation: The contract clause for dispute resolution is completely absent. This creates significant legal risk. The company standard clause, which includes negotiation, mediation, and binding arbitration, should be incorporated into the contract immediately.

flags.title: Missing Qatari Specific Clause
flags.description: The contract clause "qatar_specific_clauses" is missing, while the company standard requires specific clauses related to Qatari law and jurisdiction.
flags.recommendation: Insert the company standard Qatari specific clause, ensuring the specific law number and year are filled in. This clause is critical for governing disputes and ensuring contractual terms are interpreted in accordance with Qatari law.

recommendations: Insert the company standard Qatari specific clause, ensuring the specific law number and year are filled in. This clause is critical for governing disputes and ensuring contractual terms are interpreted in accordance with Qatari law.
